prompt.p: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 5 day history of a rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast. She is currently breast feeding. On examination the lump is 3 ′ 3 cm in size, fluctuant and tender. There is some overlying skin erythema.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Breast abscess) is Correct. Presents as a tender, swollen lump. Often has a significant amount of overlying skin erythema. There may be a fluctuant area, surrounded by hard areas of induration. Common in breastfeeding women.

Option B (Breast cyst) is Incorrect. Breast cysts are discrete fluid filled swellings within the breast. They are smooth and mobile and can lead to localized tenderness. They are common in premenopausal women.
Option C (Fat necrosis) is Incorrect. Occurs following trauma to the breast. Presents as a hard lump which is attached to the skin.
Option D (Fibroadenoma) is Incorrect. A fibroadenoma is a benign solitary, solid, rubbery breast lesion, which is characteristically smooth, non-tender and freely mobile. Common in young women.

Option E (Fibroadenosis) is Incorrect. Fibroadenosis is a benign breast condition where one or more lumps are present with symptoms of pain and nodularity, which are characteristically associated with the patient's menstrual cycle. Presents in pre-menopausal women.
